page.title: 04Low tide and rare species.
page.content: Low tide exposes sandbanks,mudflats and rocks so providing a variety of feeding areas for the birds. As the tide comes in, they roost in homogeneous groups on the gradually disappearing dry land. There is excitment when two species in particular arrive. Of all the S.W. estuaries, the Exe has the largest numbers of{Brent Geese}and the best Eel grass upon which the geese graze in order to replenish the weight lost on their long flight from the summer breeding grounds in Siberia.The{Avocet }is no common bird,but it has become a regular winter visitor here and in increasing numbers. They are found at the mouth of the Clyst sweeping the mud with their distintive upturned beaks.
